author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Bloody Nose, Empty Pockets’ and ‘Unidentified’
description: Watch an experimental film about bar regulars, and Tom DeLonge’s U.F.O. series returns.
content: BLOODY NOSE, EMPTY POCKETS (2020) Watch through virtual cinemas. This film is neither a documentary nor fiction, but rather an experimental combination of the two. Without giving too much away, it centers on a dive bar called the Roaring ’20s, and the last night of debauchery there before it closes its doors for good (or does it?). As barflies waft in and out of the establishment to bid farewell, the filmmakers — brothers Bill and Turner Ross — turn their attention to the conversations and connections the patrons make inside, celebrating the makeshift community that drinking establishments tend to provide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: The Bryan Brothers Were Ready to Call It Quits. Now They Might Need One Last Hug.
description: 2020 was supposed to be a farewell tour for Bob and Mike Bryan, the incomparable tennis twins, who have long been the darlings of doubles. Then coronavirus canceled it. Will they try again?
content: Bob and Mike Bryan had a really good plan. One last whirl around the world for this unmatched identical twin doubles team. Collect some prize money, doff their caps in Melbourne and Paris and at Wimbledon, then end in one big blanket of tennis love at the U.S. Open in New York, where they have won their home-country slam five times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: ‘Not a Welcoming Name’: Calls to Drop ‘Plantation’ Gain Steam Nationwide
description: Across the country, people are pushing to change the names of cities, neighborhoods and gated communities that include the word “plantation.”
content: When Dharyl Auguste was 3 years old, he and his parents packed all of their belongings and left their home in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, to immigrate to the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Chores Galore
description: Honey, do this Samuel A. Donaldson puzzle. Let us know if you need a hand.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This has to be intentional, right? Today’s puzzle is a sequel to last Sunday’s ticked-off boxes; maybe next week we’ll get to take summer vacation, cast off our mantles of constant responsibility and solve something with a beach theme.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Puerto Rico Presidential Democratic Primary Election Results 2020
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pat Cummings
title: 3 Picture Books: How to Hike, Camp, Relax in the Great Outdoors
description: For families ready to roam free, these visually-driven stories celebrate the physical joys of wide-open spaces.
content: On limited outings in my Brooklyn neighborhood, children I see riding atop their dads’ shoulders or lounging in strollers are all wearing masks. Without having much to compare it to, their sci-fi pandemic version of life is, simply, life. No telling what sort of impact all this will have on their tender psyches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: 5 Killed in Hostage Crisis at Church in South Africa
description: The attack may have been motivated by a feud between church members, the police said.
content: JOHANNESBURG — South African police said five people were dead and more than 40 were arrested after an early-morning hostage crisis at a church near Johannesburg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: Can These Markets Be Trusted?
description: After a calamitous drop in March, the stock market has had a ferocious rally, despite a cascade of awful news. How can investors cope?
content: The stock market is often a puzzle, but lately it has been more difficult than usual to understand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: ​Paik Sun-yup, South Korea’s First Four-Star General, Dies at 99
description: Considered a Korean War hero by the U.S. and South Korean militaries, he was a deeply divisive figure at home. Many also saw him as a traitor who collaborated with Japanese colonizers.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — Paik Sun-yup, South Korea’s first four-star general, who was lionized as a Korean War hero by the South Korean and United States militaries but dismissed by many in his country as a traitor, died on Friday. He was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: A #MeToo Moment Emerges for Military Women After Soldier’s Killing
description: Women in the military say the horrific killing of Army Specialist Vanessa Guillen has swept the nation, galvanizing even civilians to the cause.
content: WASHINGTON — As the #MeToo movement gained ground, propelled by stories of women in Hollywood, the news media, restaurants and other industries, women in the military have remained in the shadows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman
title: Caught Between Indian and Chinese Troops, at 15,000 Feet
description: Ladakh is a place of high-altitude pastures, lonely herders and desolate moonscapes — and a byword for intractable geopolitical disputes.
content: NEW DELHI — First it was cellphone towers, new roads and surveillance cameras, popping up on the Chinese side of the disputed Himalayan border with India.Then it was more run-ins between troops on each side, pushing, shoving and eventually getting into fistfights.Then, about three years ago, Indian soldiers spotted their Chinese foes carrying iron bars with little numbers written on them — a weapon apparently issued as standard gear, and a sign that the Chinese were gearing up for hand-to-hand combat.“This is how China operates,” said J.P. Yadav, a recently retired official with the Indo-Tibetan Border Police, on the Indian side. “These are very planned things.”Now, weeks after a deadly brawl erupted along the border, thousands of Chinese and Indian troops are amassed over a contentious, jagged line in one of the most remote places on earth. Satellite photos reveal a major Chinese buildup, including a blizzard of new tents, new storage sheds, artillery pieces and even tanks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: In Texas Beach City, Out-of-Towners Drove In an Outbreak
description: A month ago, Corpus Christi had hardly any cases of coronavirus and business was booming. Now it is struggling to contain one of the state’s fastest growing outbreaks. What happened?
content: CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — As recently as early June, days went by with hardly anyone testing positive for the coronavirus. A single case one day. Three the next. Then zero. Zero. Zero.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: The Republicans Who Want to Destroy Trump
description: Their party’s a lost cause. America isn’t.
content: Should you have any doubt about how passionately George Conway and the other Never Trumpers at the Lincoln Project want to defeat the president, check out their ads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: The Mistakes That Will Haunt Our Legacy
description: As we topple statues, let’s also search for our own moral blind spots.
content: As we pull down controversial statues and reassess historical figures, I’ve been wondering what our great-grandchildren will find bewilderingly immoral about our own times — and about us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Liar, Liar, Nation on Fire
description: I’m positive that Trump’s toxic.
content: WASHINGTON — Sleepy Joe and Creepy Joe haven’t worked. So now they’re trying Sticky-Fingered Joe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck, Apoorva Mandavilli and Benedict Carey
title: How to Reopen Schools: What Science and Other Countries Teach Us
description: The pressure to bring American students back to classrooms is intense, but the calculus is tricky with infections still out of control in many communities.
content: As school districts across the United States consider whether and how to restart in-person classes, their challenge is complicated by a pair of fundamental uncertainties: No nation has tried to send children back to school with the virus raging at levels like America’s, and the scientific research about transmission in classrooms is limited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Even as Covid-19 Looms, an M.L.B. Rookie Is Ready to Play
description: Seattle Mariners outfielder Kyle Lewis never wavered in his decision to play in baseball’s truncated season. Now he’s just got to get used to wearing a mask and not spitting.
content: Along with the rest of the world, athletes have had their careers upended by the coronavirus pandemic. They are giving The New York Times an intimate look at their journeys in periodic installments through the rest of the year. Read Lewis’s first installment here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Grizzly Bears Around Yellowstone Can Stay on Endangered Species List, Court Rules
description: The decision by a federal appeals court protects about 700 bears in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem from being hunted.
content: Those 700 or so grizzly bears around Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks are safe — at least for now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Metropolitan Opera Will Livestream Its Biggest Stars
description: Starting on July 18, 12 professionally shot recitals will be broadcast from idyllic locations around the world. The price of admission: $20.
content: For months, the Metropolitan Opera has been streaming operas from its extensive video archive each night, a program that has helped it attract tens of thousands of new donors. The At-Home Gala the company broadcast in April, with live performances filmed on smartphones by singers around the world, was watched by 750,000 people.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In Latin America, the Pandemic Threatens Equality Like Never Before
description: Over the past two decades, inequality in Latin America had fallen to the lowest point in its recorded history. The pandemic threatens to reverse that. We traveled 1,000 miles across Colombia to document this critical moment.
content: Over the past two decades, inequality in Latin America had fallen to the lowest point in its recorded history. The pandemic threatens to reverse that. We traveled 1,000 miles across Colombia to document this critical moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: For Oklahoma Tribe, Vindication at Long Last
description: After decades of betrayals and broken treaties, the Supreme Court ruled that much of Oklahoma is their land, after all.
content: The sorrow and death of the Trail of Tears were still fresh when a band of Muscogee (Creek) people gathered by an oak tree in 1836 to deposit the ashes of the ceremonial fires they had carried across America and begin a new home in the West. It was called Tulasi, or “Old Town.” Tulsa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Marcus and Jonah Engel Bromwich
title: What’s the Value of Harvard Without a Campus?
description: Many first-generation, low-income Harvard students feel that the elite institution has failed them.
content: Dumebi Adigwe, a rising sophomore studying mathematics at Harvard University, has no idea where she is going to live. This week, Harvard announced it would allow only up to 40 percent of its nearly 6,800 undergraduates on campus in the fall, the vast majority of them freshmen, and that all classes would be held online.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 11, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 11, 2020.
content: An article on Friday about rising coronavirus infections misidentified the state where Chris Sununu is the governor. It is New Hampshire, not Vermont.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies and Alix Strauss
title: Hunger Is Worsening. Here Are 7 Ways New Yorkers Are Addressing It.
description: Pastors, theater technicians and nonprofit leaders are repurposing their organizations to create and distribute meals.
content: The number of food-insecure New York City residents has doubled to about two million since the onset of the pandemic. But just as quickly as the need escalated, so, too, did new solutions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodi Levine
title: Make Beads From Your Newspaper
description: All it takes is your trusty Times, a little glue and these templates.
content: For so many reasons, right now is the perfect time to start a soothing and gratifying craft project. It’s even better when you can use what you have, like the very newspaper you are holding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Knoll
title: N.H.L. Owners and Players Approve New C.B.A. and Return-to-Play Plan
description: The approval cements the league’s plan to begin an expanded playoff tournament in August, and ensures labor peace at least through 2026.
content: The N.H.L.’s owners and players union announced on Friday that they had officially approved a new labor agreement that will last through 2026 and, more immediately, will allow them to proceed with plans to complete the 2019-20 season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Tackle Reopening Choices as a Couple
description: The world is reopening, and differing levels of anxiety can strain already tense relationships. Here are some strategies for getting through it together.
content: Around the world, couples are struggling to cope with the stress that comes with reopening cities and towns (and the pausing or rolling back that, in some places, has ensued). For some, tension has run high for months: As Eric Spiegelman, a podcasting executive based in Los Angeles, tweeted in April, “My wife and I play this fun game during quarantine, it’s called ‘Why Are You Doing It That Way?’ and there are no winners.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers, Derrick Bryson Taylor and Heather Murphy
title: Trump Adds Roger Stone to His List of Pardons and Commutations
description: The president’s decision to commute Mr. Stone’s sentence continues a pattern of his presidency: granting clemency to friends whose cases resonate with him personally.
content: President Trump on Friday commuted the sentence of Roger J. Stone Jr., a longtime friend and former campaign adviser who had openly expressed loyalty to him throughout a congressional investigation into ties between Mr. Trump’s 2016 campaign and Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Fact-Checking Biden on the Coronavirus and His Own Record
description: The presumptive Democratic nominee has assailed President Trump’s pandemic response and sought to shore up his left flank.
content: Since effectively securing the Democratic nomination in April, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has focused his low-profile campaign on hammering President Trump’s handling of the coronavirus epidemic. We rounded up some inaccurate claims in his recent remarks.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Perfect Peach Poundcake
description: Make Jerrelle Guy’s recipe, Ali Slagle’s shrimp scampi, and more recipes.
content: The week’s most popular dishes include Jerrelle Guy’s peach poundcake (above), Ali Slagle’s summer shrimp scampi and Eric Kim’s cucumber “quick kimchi.” Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch and Allyson Waller
title: Presidential Pardons and Commutations, From Whiskey Rebellion to Roger Stone
description: President Trump’s commutation of his friend Roger Stone’s prison term is part of a tradition of controversial pardons going back to George Washington.
content: President Trump’s move on Friday to commute the 40-month prison sentence of the political operative Roger J. Stone Jr., a longtime friend of the president’s, is far from the first time the use of that presidential power has raised eyebrows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: After an Arrest at a Black Lives Matter Protest: Deportation Proceedings
description: A Phoenix activist was supporting one cause, and caught up in the unresolved fight of another.
content: PHOENIX — Máxima Guerrero had seen it before: young people gathering in anger and frustration, not waiting for the guidance of major organizations or longtime political leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Business Leaders Urge Trump to Leave DACA Alone After Court Ruling
description: Executives with companies including Target, Apple, Google and Facebook warned the president that any actions related to DACA would disrupt the economy and affect the battle against the coronavirus.
content: A group of prominent business leaders urged President Trump on Saturday to leave in place a program affecting roughly 800,000 young immigrants who are shielded from deportation, saying it would disrupt the economy and impact the battle against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Putting Heroes, and Traitors, Where They Belong
description: The military should rechristen bases named for Confederates. Better options are not hard to find.
content: African-Americans were nonpersons in the eyes of the state when the federal government started to name U.S. Army installations for Confederate officers. Black people in the South were being lynched with impunity for such offenses as seeking the vote, competing with white people in business or simply failing to give way on the sidewalk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amna A. Akbar
title: The Left Is Remaking the World
description: “Defund the police” and “cancel rent” aren’t reforms, but paths to revolution.
content: The uprisings in response to the killing of George Floyd are far different from anything that has come before. Not just because they may be the largest in our history, or that seven weeks in, people are still in the streets (even if the news media has largely moved on). But also because, for the last few years, organizers have been thinking boldly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard A. Friedman
title: Trump Says He ‘Aced’ a Cognition Test. What Does That Tell Us?
description: If the president wants to impress us with his intellect, he should take the SAT.
content: President Trump said on Thursday that he “aced” a cognitive test administered at the Walter Reed National Military Medical Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corina Knoll, Ali Watkins and Michael Rothfeld
title: ‘I Couldn’t Do Anything’: The Virus and an E.R. Doctor’s Suicide
description: Dr. Lorna Breen was unflappable — until she faced a new enemy.
content: On an afternoon in early April, while New York City was in the throes of what would be the deadliest days of the coronavirus pandemic, Dr. Lorna M. Breen found herself alone in the still of her apartment in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Steven Lee Myers
title: Defying U.S., China and Iran Near Trade and Military Partnership
description: The investment and security pact would vastly extend China’s influence in the Middle East, throwing Iran an economic lifeline and creating new flash points with the United States.
content: Iran and China have quietly drafted a sweeping economic and security partnership that would clear the way for billions of dollars of Chinese investments in energy and other sectors, undercutting the Trump administration’s efforts to isolate the Iranian government because of its nuclear and military ambitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Writer for Tucker Carlson Resigns After ‘Abhorrent’ Online Posts Are Revealed
description: Fox News condemned Blake Neff, a writer for “Tucker Carlson Tonight,” after he was revealed as the pseudonymous author of racist and misogynist online messages.
content: A writer for the Fox News star Tucker Carlson resigned after he was revealed as the pseudonymous author of several years’ worth of racist, sexist and obscene posts on an online message board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: Georgia. Ohio. Texas. Democrats Tell Biden to Go Big (He’s Being Cautious).
description: This election, some Democrats argue, offers the party the provocative possibility of a new path to the presidency, even as others warn against overconfidence.
content: WASHINGTON — With President Trump’s poll numbers sliding in traditional battlegrounds as well as conservative-leaning states, and money pouring into Democratic campaigns, Joseph R. Biden Jr. is facing rising pressure to expand his ambitions, compete aggressively in more states and press his party’s advantage down the ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: Coronavirus Fears Stem the Flow at Atomic Liquors, Las Vegas’s Oldest Bar
description: Nevada shut bars again after the virus surged. While restaurants remain open, customers find it’s not the same.
content: LAS VEGAS — At midnight on Friday, bars across Las Vegas and Reno shut down for a second time in six months. With the coronavirus surging, the governor of Nevada had ordered it, and Las Vegas’s oldest freestanding bar, Atomic Liquors, was no exception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Writer for Tucker Carlson Resigns After ‘Abhorrent’ Online Posts Are Revealed
description: Fox News condemned Blake Neff, a writer for “Tucker Carlson Tonight,” after he was revealed as the pseudonymous author of racist and misogynist online messages.
content: A writer for the Fox News star Tucker Carlson resigned after he was revealed as the pseudonymous author of several years’ worth of racist, sexist and obscene posts on an online message board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Trump, in Florida, Seeks to Quell Doubts About His Opposition to Maduro
description: In his recent book, John Bolton, the president’s former national security adviser, recounted how Mr. Trump disparaged Venezuela’s opposition leader, Juan Guaidó, and was impressed by Mr. Maduro’s resilience.
content: President Trump renewed his opposition on Friday to Venezuela’s socialist dictator, Nicolás Maduro, showcasing a hard-line position popular with Florida’s Latino voters and accusing his presumptive Democratic rival, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., of supporting “pro-Communist policies” across Latin America.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: As Paper Withers, a Reporter Dares to Ask Why
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 11, 2020.
content: “Evan is the voice of the voiceless. He speaks for the little people. If we lose him, we’re in trouble.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Scientists Say You Can Cancel the Noise but Keep Your Window Open
description: Researchers in Singapore developed a system that’s sort of like noise-canceling headphones for your whole apartment.
content: Car alarms, jackhammers, a drunken argument and the rumble of the No. 7 train passing overhead. It is the glorious urban symphony that pours into a typical New York City apartment building day and night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: 10 Steps to Take to Try to Prevent Your Own Eviction
description: Some federal relief is about to expire. Local assistance is spotty. Congress may not act quickly. Here’s how to get help, or help yourself.
content: If you have a mortgage and can’t afford to pay it because of fallout from the coronavirus, you may be able to push off your payments for several months, or even into next year. But if you’re struggling to pay your rent, your options are probably much more limited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein and Eliza Shapiro
title: ‘I Don’t Want to Go Back’: Many Teachers Are Fearful and Angry Over Pressure to Return
description: Teachers say crucial questions about how schools will stay clean, keep students physically distanced and prevent further spread of the virus have not been answered.
content: Many of the nation’s 3.5 million teachers found themselves feeling under siege this week as pressure from the White House, pediatricians and some parents to get back to physical classrooms intensified — even as the coronavirus rages across much of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Fire Badly Damages San Gabriel Mission in California
description: The fire broke out one day after $200,000 in renovations had been completed at the church, which is more than 200 years old.
content: A fire early on Saturday morning destroyed the roof and badly damaged the interior of San Gabriel Mission, a Catholic church in California that is more than 200 years old and considered to be the “birthplace” of the Los Angeles region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Chinese Decade
description: The coronavirus has given Beijing a strategic opportunity — but one that might not last.
content: It is quite extraordinary that a pandemic originating in a Chinese province, a disease whose initial cover-up briefly seemed likely to deal a grave blow to the Communist regime, has instead given China a geopolitical opportunity unlike any enjoyed by an American rival since at least the Vietnam War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Drucker
title: Edward Kleinbard, Tax Lawyer Turned Reformer, Dies at 68
description: After advising multinationals for 30 years, he began teaching and writing, criticizing corporate tax dodging and pressing for higher taxes to combat inequality.
content: Edward Kleinbard, a prominent tax lawyer who helped global corporations find creative ways to cut their taxes before he moved to academia and shined a light on the practices of the types of companies he had once advised, died on June 28 in Los Angeles. He was 68.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Diagramless Crossword
description: Alex Eaton-Salners presents us with an uphill battle.
content: DIAGRAMLESS CROSSWORD — I hope people look forward to the diagramless puzzle, especially when it’s — drumroll — asymmetrical. That indicates a picture puzzle, because the entries have been freed from their usual mirror-image or bilateral lockdown for a good reason, to make a pattern that the solver comes upon or ferrets out. We’ve recently had a house with a chimney from Alex Eaton-Salners, a René Magritte pipe and a number three (which happens to be a hint to getting started today).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Lucius Barker, Expert on Race in American Politics, Dies at 92
description: He was a passionate Jesse Jackson delegate at the 1984 Democratic National Convention and, later, a mentor to future politicians like Senator Cory Booker.
content: Lucius J. Barker, a revered political scientist and professor whose professional expertise in race in American politics informed his personal role as a delegate for Jesse Jackson at the 1984 Democratic National Convention, died on June 21 at his home in Menlo Park, Calif. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Valentina Sampaio Is the First Transgender Model for Sports Illustrated
description: The Brazilian model, who is in the magazine’s swimsuit issue, was also the first transgender woman to work for Victoria’s Secret and grace the cover of Vogue magazine.
content: Valentina Sampaio made history on Friday, becoming the first transgender woman to be featured in the Sports Illustrated swimsuit issue, the magazine said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan and Erica L. Green
title: As Trump Demanded Schools Reopen, His Experts Warned of ‘Highest Risk’
description: A briefing packet for federal emergency response teams details the steps schools should take to reopen safely.
content: WASHINGTON — Federal materials for reopening schools, shared the week President Trump demanded weaker guidelines to do so, said fully reopening schools and universities remained the “highest risk” for the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: For 20 Years, His Firm Called Him Antoine. Now Mohamed Is Suing.
description: Mohamed Amghar, a retired software sales manager in France, has filed a discrimination complaint against his former employer, accusing the company of making him use a traditional French name at work.
content: PARIS — Mohamed Amghar was a 40-year-old software salesman in the final stages of interviewing for a new job in November 1996 when, in his telling, his future boss made a request that left him speechless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Trump Claims Credit for 2018 Cyberattack on Russia
description: The move was intended to deter Russians from interfering in the midterm elections, and serve as a test of America’s capability to protect the 2020 elections.
content: President Trump took credit late last week for a cyberattack on Russia’s Internet Research Agency two years ago, citing it as evidence that he has responded strongly to Russian provocations, despite considerable evidence that he has often excused Moscow’s aggressions in cyberspace and on European territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Tiffany May
title: To ‘Protect Young Minds,’ Hong Kong Moves to Overhaul Schools
description: China’s leaders have pushed the territory to revamp an education system they see as having bred young rebels who have helped drive pro-democracy protests.
content: Starting this fall, schools in Hong Kong will display colorful new government-issued posters declaring that “freedom comes with responsibilities.” Administrators may now call the police if anyone insults the Chinese national anthem on campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: California Parents Agree to Plead Guilty in College Admissions Scandal
description: Prosecutors said Todd and Diane Blake paid $250,000 to fraudulently gain their daughter’s admission to the University of Southern California as a volleyball recruit.
content: A California couple have agreed to plead guilty to charges that they paid $250,000 to fraudulently gain their daughter’s admission to the University of Southern California as a volleyball recruit, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: In Rare Public Comments, Mueller Defends Prosecution of Roger Stone
description: Breaking his silence, the former special counsel rebutted President Trump’s attacks on the Russia investigation and said Mr. Stone had been prosecuted “because he committed federal crimes.”
content: WASHINGTON — The former special counsel Robert S. Mueller III broke his long silence on Saturday to defend his prosecution of Roger J. Stone Jr., forcefully rebutting President Trump’s claims that the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election was political and illegitimate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: In Commuting Stone’s Sentence, Trump Goes Where Nixon Would Not
description: Senator Mitt Romney called the commutation an act of “unprecedented, historic corruption.” Attorney General William P. Barr privately argued against clemency for the president’s friend.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump has said he learned lessons from President Richard M. Nixon’s fall from grace, but in using the power of his office to keep his friend and adviser Roger J. Stone Jr. out of prison he has now crossed a line that even Mr. Nixon in the depths of Watergate dared not cross.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: In Rare Public Comments, Mueller Defends Prosecution of Roger Stone
description: Breaking his silence, the former special counsel rebutted President Trump’s attacks on the Russia investigation and said Mr. Stone had been prosecuted “because he committed federal crimes.”
content: WASHINGTON — The former special counsel Robert S. Mueller III broke his long silence on Saturday to defend his prosecution of Roger J. Stone Jr., forcefully rebutting President Trump’s claims that the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election was political and illegitimate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John F. Wasik
title: At a Time of Financial Stress, 401(k) Fees Matter More Than Ever
description: These expenses always eat away at savings balances, but as the pandemic drags on, savers should be especially aware of how to keep them down.
content: John C. Bogle, founder of the Vanguard Group, had a mantra throughout his long career in the mutual fund industry: “Costs matter.” The amount of fees you pay to a third party to manage your money eats into your retirement savings. That has never been more important, although it is probably not foremost on your mind right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Bulk of an Experiment
description: Kameron Austin Collins pushes us to our limits.
content: A note on 58D, which is incorrectly clued. The crossword editors write: “While Wall-E pronounces the name “EE-vuh,” it’s actually spelled EVE, which stands for Extraterrestrial Vegetation Evaluator.” The clue has been changed to ___ Air (carrier to Taiwan) in electronic formats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: Judge Orders Delay of First Federal Execution in 17 Years
description: The Justice Department immediately appealed the injunction, issued after family members of the victims of the crime argued that the coronavirus made it unsafe for them to travel to witness the execution.
content: WASHINGTON — With the Justice Department scheduled on Monday to carry out the death penalty for the first time in 17 years, a federal judge in Indiana temporarily suspended the plan on Friday after family members of the victims sought a delay, saying they could not safely travel to witness the execution because of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Herrman
title: Who Gets the Banhammer Now?
description: In a single week, some of the internet’s biggest platforms banned users and groups they had tolerated for years. What changed?
content: In a typical year, a good way for a company to handle an announcement it hoped to bury is to schedule it before a nice long holiday weekend. This is one way to interpret the last week of June online, when several internet giants took decisive action against mostly far-right communities and users, many of whom who had been sources of controversy for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: What Are the Quarantine Rules for Returning New Yorkers?
description: Those coming from a restricted state must isolate, but you can’t be barred from entering your own building.
content: Q: I have been staying in Florida during the pandemic, but am now planning to return to my Manhattan co-op. Do the quarantine restrictions apply to New York residents? If I inform my co-op that I’ve been in Florida, could they keep me from coming back to my apartment, or stop me from leaving if I need to go out to get groceries?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Live: Louisiana Presidential Primary Election Results 2020
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Ragaa el-Gedawy, Cherished Star of Egyptian Cinema, Dies at 85
description: She endeared herself to audiences with her grace, naturalism and comic skill. She fell ill after filming a TV series in May and died from Covid-19 in July.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith, Elian Peltier and Mark A. Walsh
title: Jack Charlton, Soccer Hero in England and Ireland, Dies at 85
description: A towering defender, he won the World Cup with his home country in 1966 and went on to coach the Irish national team to memorable runs in 1990 and 1994.
content: LEEDS, England — Jack Charlton, a soccer star who was a central part of the England team that lifted the World Cup on home soil in 1966 and who would later go on to transform Ireland’s national team as a manager, died on Friday at his home in Northumberland, in northern England. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Yacht Rock Revue Kicks Off First Night of Drive-In Concerts in Indiana
description: Live Nation’s outdoor music series attracted many captain hats, but few masks (which weren’t required).
content: NOBLESVILLE, Ind. — On a breezy, 80-degree summer night, more than a thousand, mostly middle-age smooth rock fans, many of them sporting cargo shorts and captain’s hats, danced for two hours to tunes from the 1970s and ’80s by Yacht Rock Revue, who were performing in an Indiana parking lot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Ethiopia Announces Arrests in Prominent Singer’s Killing
description: The shooting last month of Hachalu Hundessa, a hero to young Ethiopians calling for reform, was followed by unrest in which hundreds of people were killed.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Ethiopia has said that two men have been arrested in connection with the killing of Hachalu Hundessa, a well-known musician and activist whose death last month was followed by unrest in which hundreds were killed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Moss
title: Explore the Red Planet and the Pool
description: Go on a scavenger hunt for Mars Day, muse on why we swim and boogie during a dance master class.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Courtney Sullivan
title: America Needs an Emergency Meeting of the Baby-Sitters Club
description: Schools and day cares are still closed. Luckily, I have an eager 9-year-old neighbor.
content: LOUDONVILLE, N.Y. — A few weeks back, our 9-year-old neighbor, Nealy, cornered me in the driveway. Since summer camp was canceled, she said, and because she is technically too young to babysit (though fully capable of doing so), she wanted to offer her services as a mother’s helper. She would come over and watch my children — ages 20 months and just-turned-3 — so that I could get things done around the house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May and Su-Hyun Lee
title: Hindu God in a Music Video? A K-Pop Band Runs Afoul of Fans
description: A tempest over the band Blackpink’s use of a Hindu god in a video was the latest example of K-pop fans holding artists to account — while staying fiercely loyal.
content: The statue of the Hindu god Ganesha flashed onscreen for just seconds in the music video by Blackpink, an all-female K-pop band. The elephant-headed deity was shown on the floor, near a bejeweled Aladdin lamp, as a member of the band preened and rapped on a golden throne.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: By Praising Trump, Goya President Angers His Core Latino Market
description: Robert Unanue said the country was “blessed” to have the president’s leadership. Now, amid calls for a boycott, the largest Hispanic-owned food company in the U.S. is facing dismay from chefs and home cooks.
content: When Lina Baez-Rosario moved to the United States as a young girl, she missed her home in the Dominican Republic. Her parents made sure to cook with familiar flavors, to keep memories alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Reopening Schools Will Be a Huge Undertaking. It Must Be Done.
description: Officials need to think outside the school building.
content: American children need public schools to reopen in the fall. Reading, writing and arithmetic are not even the half of it. Kids need to learn to compete and to cooperate. They need food and friendships; books and basketball courts; time away from family and a safe place to spend it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Wears a Mask Publicly for the First Time
description: Louisiana’s governor ordered bars to close and said almost all residents must wear a mask. Disney World reopened, despite a surge in Florida. Thousands of Israelis protested the government’s handling of the economy.
content: President Trump on Saturday wore a mask in public for the first time, after repeated urging from aides that it was a necessary message to send to Americans resistant to covering their faces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Mark Mazzetti
title: Trump’s Clemency Came After Displays of Loyalty by Stone
description: The extraordinary decision to commute the prison sentence of an embattled adviser demonstrates how the president has managed to bend America’s legal machinery to his advantage.
content: Months before F.B.I. agents arrived in darkness at his Florida home to take him into custody, Roger J. Stone Jr. promised that he would remain loyal to his longtime friend. “I will never roll on Donald Trump,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times
